Graphical abstract New insight on the understanding of the reaction mechanisms during the CO oxidation over Ru-containing CeO2 catalysts was reported. A set of ruthenium high surface area CeO2 oxides, with two different Ru loadings, was prepared for studying the evolution of Ru and Ce species during CO oxidation reaction, using a reaction mixture of 1 % CO, 0.5 % O2, N2 balance and a contact time W/FCO = 7.4 gcat h molCO −1. The samples were characterized by SBET, XRD, DRS UV–vis, TPR, Raman spectroscopy, and XPS. Furthermore, the samples were investigated by FTIR measurements during CO oxidation under reaction conditions. The catalysts with low Ru loading (1.5 wt.%) presented higher catalytic activity than those containing a higher Ru loading (3 % wt.). The catalytic activity test results strongly depend on electronic changes observed at the interface/surface of ceria support. The characterization results and FTIR investigation during CO oxidation show that the presence of ruthenium species modifies the electronic properties of the ceria surface promoting a change at their surface where a redox-mechanism was detected. This causes the formation of surface oxygen vacancies which promotes oxygen mobility from the ceria lattice contributing to the CO oxidation. The ruthenium incorporation drastically favors the CO adsorption (carbonyl and dicarbonyl species). However, our FTIR data not shown a direct correlation between the ruthenium-carbonyl species (linear and bridged form) on the CO transformation. Further, the presence of ruthenium enhances the formation of surface oxygen vacancies, which favor the oxygen mobility from the ceria lattice toward the CO oxidation. It was found that at low temperatures (close down to the maximum conversion), the CO oxidation preferably happened on oxygen vacancy sites. Keywords CO oxidation CeO2cerium oxide FTIR under reaction conditions Ru catalyst Ruthenium 1 Introduction Drastic growth in atmospheric pollution, caused by the fast and irresponsible industrial development and growing demand in the use of automobiles for transportation, has led to rising demand for fossil fuels [1]. Among all the pollutants, carbon monoxide (CO) is a gas considered highly poisonous, which causes severe health effects and irreversible environmental damage [2,3]. One of the strategies proposed to reduce the CO emission, arising from the incomplete combustion of fossil fuels in combustion engines, is the CO oxidation through the use of catalytic converters [4,5]. The search for strategies towards reducing atmospheric CO concentration is an urgent task, which continues attracting numerous research groups focused on improving the synthesis methods and the enhancement of the catalytic performance at lower costs for this reaction [5–9]. Cerium oxide is characterized by the easy Ce3+/Ce4+ redox couple switching, being one of the most interesting materials as support in catalytic converters, due to its high oxidative capacity in the carbon monoxide oxidation reaction. Its capability to be reduced from CeO2 to Ce2O3 leads to the formation of oxides with non-stoichiometric oxygen content, which depends mainly on the oxygen partial pressure [10]. Over the last decade, there has been significant progress in the nanoscale-controlled synthesis of CeO2 materials for catalytic applications, developing novel methodologies for obtaining cerium oxide with relatively high specific surface area values [10]. The role of the textural properties (e.g. specific surface area, total pore volume, pore diameter) on the catalytic activity of ceria for various reactions, including CO oxidation, is well known [10]. Noble metals, quite active in catalytic oxidation of carbon monoxide, can be considered as the main part of commercial catalysts [9]. Particularly, Au, Pt, Pd, and Rh are well known because of their outstanding role as an active part of catalysts for low-temperature CO oxidation [9,11]. Recently, ruthenium-based catalysts have been reported in oxidation reactions showing excellent catalytic activity, at low temperatures [12–15]. Eguchi et al. described the excellent efficiency of Ru-based catalysts supported on CeO2 oxide for oxidation reactions [16–18]. The authors compared the catalytic performance of Ru catalysts with those based on Pt, Pd, and Rh metals, confirming that Ru-based catalysts performed more efficiently in the oxidation of ethyl acetate and yielded the highest catalytic activity and CO2 selectivity [19]. H.-T. Chen [20] reported a first-principles study on the interaction and for the CO oxidation mechanism over Ru-modified CeO2 surface. Their results displayed that the Ru incorporation into of ceria framework increases the oxygen vacancy formation, while the surface Ru addition may suppress the oxygen vacancy formation. Physisorbed CO and CO2 molecules, and chemisorbed CO molecule were observed on the of Ru-doped CeO2 surface, while on the pure CeO2 surface only a physisorbed CO molecule was adsorbed. The incorporation of Ru ions into of ceria lattice as substitutional of Ce atoms, can activate the oxygen supply during the CO oxidation and improvised the CO2 desorption. Besides, reported that the Ru-doped CeO2 surface, increases the oxygen storage capacity of the samples, promoted the adsorption of molecular O2 on the O vacancy, forming surface O adsorbed species, which at in a later step involved in the CO oxidation. P. Singh et al. [21] reported the nanocrystalline Ru-containing CeO2 material three-way catalyst. The authors reported that the lattice oxygen is highly activated because of the substitution of Ru+4 ions in CeO2 structure and it plays an important role in low-temperature CO oxidation and the complete conversion of reduction of NO into N2. In this respect, the present investigation aims to generate active high surface area Ru(x)-CeO2 catalysts for the carbon monoxide oxidation. FTIR studies under reaction conditions during CO oxidation were performed to determine the type of species and oxygen vacancies that are formed during the reaction, to better understand the nature of the mechanisms of the reaction under Ru-CeO2 catalysts and to further to increase the catalytic stability of the prepared materials. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst synthesis Pure CeO2 oxide was prepared from Ce(C2H3O2)3∙H2O, (99.99 % purity, Sigma-Aldrich) dissolved in deionized water and added to a stoichiometric amount of ethylene glycol (99.8 % J. T. Baker). Afterward, 10 mL of a 10 % (w/w) solution of PVP surfactant was also added. The mixture was heated at 130 °C for 30 min in a Synthos 3000 microwave equipment. Subsequently, the obtained solution was dried at 110 °C and calcined at 400 °C. To prepare the Ru-containing CeO2 oxide, the required amount of Ce(C2H3O2)3∙H2O was dissolved in deionized water, while Ru3(CO)12 (99.99 % purity, Sigma-Aldrich) was dissolved in isopropyl alcohol (Sigma-Aldrich). Then, an appropriate amount of both solutions were mixed in order to obtain a Ru-loading of 1.5 and 3 % wt, which was heated at 130 °C in the microwave equipment for about 30 min. The formed gel was dried at 110 °C for 2 h and finally calcined at 400 °C for 3 h [22]. The obtained catalysts containing 1 and 3 % wt. of ruthenium are labeled as Ru(1.5)CeO2 and Ru(3)CeO2 respectively. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The FTIR investigation under reaction conditions during CO oxidation was performed in an Agilent 660 spectrophotometer, using an ISRI transmission heated-cell and in-situ high-low pressure infrared reactor with CaF2 windows. Self-supporting wafers of the catalysts with a thickness of 60 mg cm−2 were prepared by pressing the powdered samples at a pressure of 8 × 103 kg cm−2 for 20 min. Before experiments, the self-supporting wafers were flushed in a gas reducing mixture (H2/N2 25 vol % H2), gradually increasing the temperature up to 300 °C, keeping it an hour. Then, the sample was cooled down to room temperature. After the reduction treatment stage, the flowing gas was changed from H2/N2 mixture to the reaction mixture gas (CO/O2/N2 molar ratio of 1/0.5/98.5) under a contact time W/FCO = 7.4 gcat h molCO −1. The temperature of the FTIR reactor/cell was increased from room temperature up to 300 °C, at a rate of 2.5 °C/min. The infrared spectra were recorded with a resolution of 4 cm−1 every 10 °C of temperature increase. Textural properties were determined from the adsorption-desorption isotherms of nitrogen at −196 °C, recorded with a Micromeritics TriStar 3000 apparatus. The crystalline structure was studied by X-ray diffraction (XRD) in a Bruker D8 Advance with Cu–Kα radiation operating at 30 keV and 20 mA, with a step size of 0.021°/min, from 10 to 70 (2θ). The UV–vis-DRS spectra of the samples were recorded in a Varian Cary-5000 UV–vis spectrophotometer. Micro-Raman spectroscopy was carried out at room temperature in a micro-Raman system (Labram model of Dilor) equipped with a 20 mW He-Ne laser emitting at 532 nm. The X-ray photoelectron spectra of the catalysts were recorded using a VG Escalab 200R spectrometer equipped with a hemispherical electron analyzer and an Mg Kα (hν =1253.6 eV) X-ray source. The temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) of the samples was carried out in a Quantachrome model ChemBET Pulsar equipment. Before the experiments, the samples were dried at 120 °C in N2 flow and cooled down at ambient temperature under the same gas flow. TPR measurements were performed with an H2/N2 gas flow mixture (5% H2 v/v) from room temperature to 850 °C, at a heating rate of 10 °C/min. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Structural characterization Table 1 shows, the specific area (SBET), average pore volume (Vp), and average pore diameter (Dp) of the catalysts and the ceria support (CeO2). The adsorption isotherms (not shown here) of CeO2 support and Ru/CeO2 catalysts were type IV in accordance with the IUPAC classification. The pure ceria oxide shows a specific area value of 118 m2 g−1. This value is higher in comparison with typical surface area values commonly reported for this oxide. The ruthenium addition increases drastically the surface area value, displaying the higher SBET value for the Ru(3.0)CeO2 sample (155 m2 g−1), which is very close to the SBET value of the Ru(1.5)CeO2 sample of 148 m2 g−1. The Ru(3.0)CeO2 sample shows both Dp (4.9 nm) and Vp (0.16 cm3 g−1) higher values, in comparison to the other two samples. Then, one can conclude that the Ru addition increases the structural mesoporosity, and consequently improves the corresponding textural parameters. XRD patterns of the calcined samples are presented in Fig. 1 . All samples showed characteristic peaks of the fluorite phase from the pure ceria oxide. No reflection peaks characteristic of ruthenium particles were detected, suggesting, that some amount of ruthenium has been included in the crystallographic cell of CeO2; while some other remaining quantity could have been thoroughly dispersed on its surface, having very small particle diameters, which makes difficult its detection [23,24]. The presence of ruthenium produced changes in the shape of the full-wide at half maximum (FWHM) of the peak at 28.5° (2θ), presumably caused by defect formation in the crystalline lattice of CeO2, during the synthesis procedure [25–27]. Further, an XRD-Rietveld refinement for the Ce-Ru catalysts and the CeO2 support was performed. The ruthenium incorporation produced a decrease in the crystal size of CeO2 oxide (Table 1). The smaller crystal size was observed for the Ru(3.0)CeO2 sample (8.1 nm). Refinement of the diffraction patterns was performed on the most intense peak of the CeO2 support (28.5° in 2θ), calibrating with the graphite peak, near to 26.5°. Table 1 shows, the CeO2 lattice expansion of the samples. One can notice a slight expansion of the CeO2 lattice apparently caused by the incorporation of ruthenium ions into the CeO2 oxide, reaching a maximum for the sample with a higher Ru nominal content, even though this parameter is close to the Ru(1.5)CeO2 sample; which could imply that there is a solubility limit of Ru within the crystallographic network of CeO2. Then, the lattice expansion observed could be related to structural defects due to the formation of Ce3+ species in the CeO2 lattice, being promoted by metallic cations incorporation [28–30]. Chen et al. [31] reported that Ce4+ reduction to Ce3+ is associated with anion vacancies, and if the amount of Ce3+ is higher than Ce4+ a framework expansion may take place. Da Silva et al. [32] in a DFT study also considered that the expansion of the ceria cell could be produced as a consequence of a change in the oxidation state of Ce atoms, from Ce4+ to Ce3+, and due to the high stability of partially reduced CeO2 in a cubic-like structure. Several reports have suggested that the formation of surface oxygen vacancies, could favor Ce4+ to Ce3+ reduction [33–38]. Raman spectra of the Ru-containing ceria catalysts and pure ceria support are displayed in Fig. 2 . The Raman spectra showed four bands located at 459, 573, and 839 cm−1. The Raman shift signal at 459 cm−1 corresponds to the triple degenerated mode (F2g) of CeO2 [39,40]. This vibrational mode is a symmetric vibration of eight oxygen atoms around each ceria cation [40,41]. The interaction of another metal ion with the oxygen atoms associated with Ce4+ ions would lead to the lowering of the F2g Raman band of CeO2 oxide. It is seen that the Raman shift signal at 459 cm−1 decreases its intensity as a function of the metal content. A drastic decrement on the intensity of this band was observed on the sample with the highest ruthenium content (Ru(3)CeO2), which could indicate that on this sample the cerium surface covered by ruthenium ions is higher in comparison with their counterpart Ru(1.5)CeO2 sample. Besides, it was observed that this band was shifted towards lower Raman signal values as a function of Ru loading, with a more prominent shift for Ru(3)CeO2 sample (450.4 cm−1), even though this displacement was close to the Ru(1.5)CeO2 sample (453 cm−1). Lee et al. [41] reported that the F2g peak shift towards lower Raman values and its decreasing in intensity was related to a corresponding increase in oxygen vacancies. They also reported that the downward shift to lower frequency values is mostly due to the lattice expansion of the ceria framework and softening of modes when oxygen vacancies were created. The effect of ruthenium on the formation of CeO2 lattice defects could also be observed at the band around 573 cm−1, which is typical of the presence of defects which modifies the bulk oxygen vibration [39,40]. This band is less intense for pure ceria support, as shown in Fig. 2, however, once ruthenium was incorporated, the intensity of that signal increases, reaching the maximum intensity for the sample with the smaller Ru content, suggesting that for a lower ruthenium content on the CeO2 surface, higher oxygen defects are displayed in the Ru(1.5)CeO2 sample. Finally, the Raman signal at 839 cm−1 is characteristic of the presence of peroxide species, which are important for oxidation reactions [39,41–44]. The formation of peroxide species was improved by the Ru incorporation. The peroxide formation on the higher Ru loading sample was lower, in comparison with the Ru(1.5)CeO2 sample. Therefore, higher oxygen vacancies were observed on the Ru(1.5)CeO2 sample, as indicated above. 3.2 Reducibility and electronic characterization It was investigated the ruthenium incorporation effect on the electronic environment of Ce ions. Fig. 3 shows the DRS-UV electronic spectra of the Ru-containing ceria catalysts and the pure ceria support. The spectrum of the pure CeO2 support showed two intense absorption bands in the charge transference region located at 275 and 495 nm. The first absorption band at 275 nm corresponds to the transference from oxygen to cerium III (O2 − → Ce3+), while the absorption band at 340 nm is assigned to the electronic transference from oxygen to cerium IV (O2 − → Ce4+) [23,39]. Both absorption bands are affected by the ruthenium incorporation. The intensity of the Ce3+ species gradually increases as a function of ruthenium content, reaching the higher amount of the Ce3+ species for the Ru(3)CeO2 sample, which is in agreement with the lattice expansion observed in the previously discussed XRD results. Conversely, the absorption band associated with the Ce4+ species reached its highest intensity for the 1.5 % wt of ruthenium content. Then, are expected important changes in the proportions of the Ceᵟ+ species. The intensity of the Ce3+/Ce4+ ratio follows the order: Ru(3)CeO2 (1.05) > Ru(1.5)CeO2 (1.03) > CeO2 (1.02). This means that the presence of Ru ions promoted to some extent, the reduction of Ce4+ species to Ce3+ ions. This could explain that the lattice expansion observed in the XRD result is due to the formation of cerium defects produced by the Ce3+ species due to the ruthenium ions incorporation, which can be related to the increase in the intensity of the absorption band located at 275 nm. This is in agreement with the observed Raman results. DRS UV − vis spectra of Ru-containing samples displayed an additional absorption band centered at 498 nm (Fig. 3). This band is attributed to the surface plasmon (SP) resonance of Ru nanoparticles. It comes from the collective oscillations of the free conduction band electrons induced by incident electromagnetic radiation with a wavelength greatly exceeding the particle diameter. SP resonance is a signature for the presence of metallic nanoparticles [23]. This absorption band increases monotonically with the Ru content. Then, it could be assumed that for samples containing a higher Ru content, the formation of surface ruthenium nanoparticles is also increased. Then, it is possible to assume that the incorporation of ruthenium in the ceria network and the formation of metal particles on the surface occurred. H2-TPR profile was a performance to determine the reducibility of the Ce and Ru species. Fig. 4 shows H2-TPR profiles for pure CeO2 oxide and Ru-containing ceria catalysts. Two reduction peaks are noticed at 421 and 768 °C on the pure CeO2 support. Reduction peaks at 421 and 511 °C correspond to the reduction of surface Ce4+ species, while the reduction peak shown at a higher temperature (ca. 768 °C) is due to the reduction of Ce4+ species from of CeO2 bulk [45–47]. After the Ru incorporation into CeO2 material, two reductions peaks at 132−160 °C and 260 °C were observed. The peak detected at a lower temperature (132−160 °C) was attributed to the reduction of the Ru-oxide nanoparticles, as evidenced by the surface plasmon observed in DRS-UV–vis results. As expected, the lower Ru loading sample (Ru(1.5)CeO2) displayed the lower hydrogen consumption associated with the reduction of oxide Ru particles. Further, this reduction peak was observed at a higher temperature (160 °C), in comparison with its counterpart Ru(3.0)CeO2 sample (132 °C), which suggests that the interaction of Ru species with cerium oxide is stronger for the Ru(1.5)CeO2 sample. The peak at 260 °C is associated with the reduction of ruthenium species that are strongly interacting with the ceria network [47]. The hydrogen consumption related to this reduction was higher in the sample with lower ruthenium content, which can prove that a higher amount of Ru species was incorporated into of cerium framework. Moreover, the main reduction peak (421 °C) of the pure CeO2 material changed significantly to a low-temperature value after Ru doping. This reduction peak generally is associated with the formation of oxygen vacancies during the reduction of the CeO2 surface. As it is more susceptible to be reduced an oxide, it becomes easier to generate oxygen vacancies [47]. Our observations suggest that when Ru ions are incorporated into the ceria oxide, more oxygen vacancies are produced. Besides, the hydrogen consumption of this reduction peak was higher for Ru doping samples, resulting in up to 68 % higher on the Ru(1.5)CeO2 sample, in comparison with the higher Ru content sample. These results indicate higher oxygen vacancies formation on the lower Ru-containing sample, following the previously discussed results. A final remark is that the amount of reduction coming from the CeO2 bulk (ca. 768 °C) was slightly lower in samples containing ruthenium, which could confirm that the presence of ruthenium promotes the movement of oxygen from the network to the surface. The freshly reduced samples were characterized by the XPS technique to determine the effect of ruthenium addition on the chemical state of the cerium species and the ruthenium reducibility. Considering that the Ru 3d 3/2 binding energy is overlapped with the carbon 1s signal, we carry out the XPS measurement for the Ru 3p peak. The XPS spectra of Ru3p and Ce 3d core electron levels of the Ru-containing ceria catalysts and pure ceria support are shown in Fig. 5 a and b, respectively. In Table 2 , the binding energy values of the Ce 3d peaks, the deconvolution of most intense Ru 3p 3/2 spin-orbit component, as well as the Ce3+/Ce4+ and Ru/Ce surface atomic ratios of the Ru-containing ceria catalysts and pure ceria support are provided. The Ru 3p 3/2 core signal of the ruthenium containing samples displayed two-oxidation states of the Ru species, located at 461.1 and 462.6, which are associated with the presence of Ru and RuO2 compounds, respectively [46–48]. Besides, the sample with higher Ru-loading displayed a minor additional peak at 466.8 eV, which was related to the oxide Ru6+ species [48–50]. In this sample (Ru(3)CeO2 sample), the presence of the total amount of oxide Ru species was 64 %, while for the Ru(1.5)CeO2 compound it was 57 %. Therefore it is concluded, that the Ru(3)CeO2 sample has an important proportion of oxide Ru6+ species, which are less susceptible to reduction. The intensity of the XPS Ru 3p 3/2 signal is quite bigger for the high Ru-content sample in accordance with the larger amount of ruthenium and the higher Ru/Ce atomic surface ratio of this sample in comparison to the lower ruthenium content sample (Table 2). This is in agreement with the decrement in the intensity signal of the Raman shift detected at 459 cm−1, which suggests that it is due to the interaction of the ruthenium species with the surface oxygen. Moreover, considering the percentage of metallic ruthenium on the cerium surface as obtained by XPS, the Ru(3)CeO2 sample contains more metallic ruthenium on the surface (metallic Ru/Ce atomic ratio of 0.0176), in comparison with the lower Ru-loaded sample (metallic Ru/Ce atomic ratio of 0.00774), in accordance with the DRS UV–vis already discussed results. The XPS spectra of Ce 3d core electron level exhibited eight peaks corresponding to the spin-orbit doublet and satellite lines characteristic of their oxidized state (Table 2). The spin-orbit splitting is 18.4 eV. The Ce 3d 5/2 spin-orbit component showed the main features at 882.2 eV, 884.6 eV, 892.7 eV and 898.7 eV corresponding to v, v´, v´´ and v´´´ respectively, the Ce 3d3/2 spin-orbit component showed features at 902.2 eV, 904.7 eV, 907.4 eV, and 916.9 eV corresponding to u, u´, u´´ and u´´´ respectively [23]. The component v’ and u’ arise from Ce 3+ species whereas all the other components are typical of Ce 4+ species. The two additional components, labeled as v0 and u0, typical also of the Ce 3+ species, were so weak in intensity that could be not identified. Analyzing the characteristic signals of each Ce4+ and Ce3+ species, it is evident that the proportion of the Ce4+ is about 2.4–2.6 times higher than that of the proportion of Ce3+. Moreover, the Ce3+/Ce4+ surface ratio exhibits a small but still consistent variation with the ruthenium content (Table 2). The surface Ce3+/Ce4+ ratio follows the order: Ru(3)CeO2 (0.42) > Ru(1.5)CeO2 (0.41) > pure CeO2 (0.39). As the ruthenium content increases, the Ce3+/Ce4+ ratio also increases, indicating that the presence of ruthenium promoted the partial reduction of Ce4+ ions to Ce3+ species. The O/Ce atomic ratio should decrease when the surface Ce3+/Ce4+ atomic ratio increases. However, the results presented in Table 2 shows that the O/Ce atomic ratio increased, while the surface Ce3+/Ce4+ atomic ratio decreased. This could be related to the fact that the amount of the ceria exposed active centers on the surface dramatically decreased in the ruthenium loaded samples, therefore the amount of surface oxygen increases. On the other hand, it could also be possible that oxygen interacts with the ruthenium species. The higher amount of surface oxygen was observed in the Ru(1.5)CeO2 sample, followed by the Ru(3)CeO2 sample. Nevertheless, the higher amount of surface oxygen could be associated with the surface oxygen mobility, as indicated in the catalytic performance analysis section, where the Ru(1.5)CeO2 sample reached the complete CO conversion at the lower reaction temperature. 3.3 FTIR investigation of the CO oxidation reaction 3.3.1 Catalytic performance during FTIR investigation under reaction conditions during CO oxidation The results of CO conversions observed through the FTIR experiments carried out over the pristine CeO2 support and the ruthenium-containing CeO2 oxides, while the CO oxidation occurred, are shown in Fig. 6 . Oxidation of CO over Ru-containing catalysts increases as a function of temperature until reaching a maximum; thereafter the CO conversion is kept constant (Fig. 6). The pure CeO2 oxide displayed poor catalytic performance and did not show CO conversion between 25 and 160 °C. Their higher CO conversion value (near 48 %) was observed at a higher temperature (300 °C). This is because diffusion of oxygen from the bulk to the ceria surface is only activated at high temperatures, allowing oxidation of CO and regeneration of the support structure by oxygen that comes from the feed mixture [23]. Ruthenium addition improved significantly the catalytic performance, suggesting that the presence of Ru species facilitates the activation of oxygen, coming from the ceria support. The reaction temperature (T50) in correspondence of 50 % of conversion, follows the order: Ru(1.5)CeO2 (90 °C) < Ru(3)CeO2 (125 °C) << CeO2 (>300 °C). Thus, the Ru(1.5)CeO2 catalyst clearly shows a much lower T50 compared to the other two samples. This sample (Ru(1.5)CeO2) also shows the higher catalytic activity towards CO oxidation among the catalysts studied, reaching about 98 % CO conversion at 160 °C. The catalysts with higher ruthenium loading (Ru(3)CeO2) show maximum CO conversion at higher temperature values in comparison to Ru(1.5)CeO2 catalyst, reaching its maximum CO conversion at 220 °C. The fact that catalyst with higher ruthenium loading (3 wt.%) displays less CO oxidation values could be explained by the formation of higher-surface Ru or RuO2 nanoparticles, which covered the ceria surface and, hence, less oxygen from the ceria support towards the CO oxidation was available [24,25]. 3.3.2 FTIR investigation during the CO oxidation reaction FTIR spectra for pure cerium oxide during conditions of the reaction of CO oxidation varying temperature, within the range of 25−280 °C is shown in Fig. 7 . The introduction of CO, at room temperature into of the transmission reaction chamber, generates two main absorption bands at 2174 and 2122 cm−1, which corresponds to CO linearly bonded to Lewis acid sites of CeO2, specifically to Ce+4 (ν (CO) = 2174 cm−1) and Ce+3 (ν (CO) = 2120 cm−1) species [51–54]. The band at 2172 cm−1 is lightly more intense than the one located at 2120 cm−1 (Fig. 7). This fact indicates there is a greater number of Ce+4 sites than Ce+3 on the surface of CeO2 sample, as indicated by XPS (Fig. 5). The intensity of both bands decreases gradually as the temperature increases. When the temperature of the reaction chamber increased up to 160 °C, two bands of low intensity located at 2370 and 2344 cm-1 appeared simultaneously, increasing their intensity as the temperature rises. These bands are characteristic of gaseous CO2 [55–57]. The decrease in intensity of Ce+4−CO and Ce+3−CO species in the range from room temperature up to 160 °C possibly could be due to thermic CO desorption. Moreover, above 160 °C, the diminishing of adsorbed CO bands on ceria could also be due to its transformation to CO2, in accordance with the appearance of the bands associated with the CO2 species which increased their intensity as temperature also increased. FTIR spectra for the Ru(1.5)CeO2 sample during reaction conditions for the CO oxidation varying the reaction temperature are shown in Fig. 8 . Notably, the FTIR spectra were quite different as compared to those obtained with pure CeO2 sample (Fig. 7). At room temperature, the absorption bands at 2174 and 2120 cm−1 appeared. As discussed before, these bands are assigned to CO linearly bonded to Ce+4 and Ce+3 sites, respectively [52–54]. It is important to highlight that the intensity of the Ce+3−CO band is slightly bigger than the one assigned to Ce+4−CO, in accordance with the UV–vis, TPR, and XPS results (Figs. 2–5). A greater amount of Ce+3 sites in the Ru-containing ceria in comparison to pure CeO2 could be due to the presence of Ru favoring the surface reduction of ceria, as observed through the multiple characterization methods discussed above. Moreover, absorption bands found at 2058, 1988, 1968, 1945, and 1870 cm−1 were observed. Similar features were observed during the CO adsorption over ruthenium supported on different metal oxides. However, their assignment is not straightforward due to the diversity of bands that emerge in similar samples. The bands at 2058 cm−1, could be assigned to CO stretching of carbonyl species bonded to metallic Ru in the linear form [58–61]. However, other authors [58–60,62] have suggested that this band (2058 cm−1) and the one situated at 1988 cm−1 correspond to dicarbonyl species bonded on Ru° species. The bands at 1968, 1945, and 1870 cm−1 are located in a region where various authors attribute this to CO anchored to two Ru sites bridge configuration [63,64]. The absorption bands at 2058 and 1988 cm−1 grew up as a function of temperature reaching maximum intensity at approximately 160 °C. At higher temperatures, both bands decreased simultaneously. This behavior suggests that both bands correspond to the same species, specifically to ruthenium dicarbonyl species. Therefore, from our data, it follows that the CO was adsorbed on the ceria (on Ce+4 and Ce+3 sites) and on the metal sites (as Ru-dicarbonyls and carbonyls bonded to Ru atoms in bridge form). Concurrently, the two characteristic bands to CO2 in the gas phase (2370 and 2344 cm−1, Fig. 8) turned up at approximately 40 °C and their intensity increased as a function of temperature along with the experiment. The appearance of the CO2(g) related bands at a lower temperature on Ru-containing ceria; as compared to pure ceria, demonstrated that the addition of Ru to CeO2 increases drastically the catalytic performance of the samples. This improvement may arise from a high CO adsorption capacity due to the Ru presence, higher oxygen availability, and superior oxygen dissociation at a lower temperature than CeO2, which could be associated with the redox properties of CeO2 material. The absorption bands of CO molecules bonded to CeO2 (2174 and 2120 cm−1) decrease gradually in the range from room temperature up to 160 °C, and while above this temperature, it remains constant. A different behavior was observed in the absorption bands attributed to Rh°-(CO)2 (2058 and 1988 cm−1) species. Indeed, as mentioned previously, the bands increase their intensities up to 160 °C while above this temperature started to decrease their intensity. At the same temperature, a signal located at 2040 cm−1, assigned to ν (CO) vibration mode of CO on Ru° in linear form appeared (Fig. 8) [55–57]. At higher temperatures, this absorption band (2040 cm−1) shifted its frequency to 2030 cm−1 and increase its intensity. While the bands of bridged carbonyls on Ru (1968, 1945 and 1870 cm−1, (Fig. 8) remain constant until reaching a conversion of 98 % (at 160 °C). Above this temperature, a length decrease in the intensity of these FTIR signals was observed. However, at temperatures above at 160 °C, the increase in the CO conversion is minimal (2 %), therefore it cannot be established whether these species could participate in the reaction mechanism or are only desorbed. FTIR spectra for the Ru(3)CeO2 sample during reaction conditions for the CO oxidation varying the reaction temperature is shown in Fig. 9 . The observed absorption bands at room temperature are similar to the observed in IR spectra of the sample with lower ruthenium loading, which was located at 2174, 2120, 1968, 1945, and 1870 cm−1. However, their intensity is higher in all cases, indicating that there is a greater number of surface species derived from the CO adsorption, in accordance with the XPS results. Such spectra confirm that the Ru addition promotes the CO(g) surface adsorption. Nevertheless, the intensity of the absorption band at 2174 cm−1 is higher than that located at 2120 cm−1. So that there are a smaller number of Ce+3 sites in comparison to Ce+4 on the surface, as it was confirmed with the UV–vis and XPS results (Figs. 3,5 and). The results described above suggest that an increase in the Ru concentration might produce effects in the reducibility ratio of CeO2. In a previous report, we found that the presence of metallic species induces a reduction of surface oxygen of the ceria, and consequently promoting the reduction of Ce4+ species [23]. Upon temperature increasing, the absorption bands associated with the CO adsorption on Ce+n species (2174 and 2120 cm−1 bands, Fig. 9) decreased until reached a CO conversion of 92 % (at 180 °C). Above this temperature, their intensity incremented gradually. This effect is more pronounced in the band corresponding to the CO adsorbed on Ce+3 species (Fig. 9). The behavior is similar to the sample with lower Ru content (Fig. 8). Specifically, the intensity of bands corresponding to ruthenium dicarbonyl increased until 160 °C, and then the intensity of this band light disappeared progressively as a function of the increase in temperature. Similarly to what was observed in the Ru(1.5)CeO2 sample, above this temperature the increase in conversion is very low (8 %), it could not be associated with certainty if the intensity of this signal decreased due to the transformation of CO to CO2 or can be attributed simply to desorption of these species. At this temperature, a new band between 2040−2030 cm−1 was observed, which is associated with Ru°−CO species (Fig. 9). However, at a higher temperature, this band considerably increases its intensity. Similar behavior was observed in the bands corresponding to CO adsorbed on multiple Ru sites, remaining constant in the temperature range from RT up to 100 °C, and subsequently increasing their intensity. Besides, above 40 °C, the distinctive bands of the CO2(g) appeared, increasing their intensity as the temperature does. The intensities of the characteristics bands due to CO2(g) were lower in comparison to the sample with 1.5 % wt Ru content, which is in accordance with the catalytic performance of the two samples. The lower activity catalytic observed in the high Ru loaded sample may be due to a higher amount of ruthenium nanoparticles than isolated Ru species. Because the presence of surface ruthenium suppresses the formation of oxygen vacancies, on the contrary, the ruthenium atoms as dopants promote its generation [20,23,64]. 4 Reaction mechanism proposal for the CO oxidation over Ru-containing CeO2 material The FTIR spectra of pure CeO2 during the CO oxidation contained bands at 2174 cm−1 and 2120 cm−1 attributable to CO species bonded to Ce+4 and Ce+3 sites, respectively (Fig. 7). This observation is explained by CO(g) adsorbed on Lewis acid sites as shown in step 1 of Fig. 10 . Presumably, the oxygen vacancies on the metal oxides surface (including CeO2), can act as O2 adsorption sites. Indeed, the presence of Ce+3 sites on pure CeO2 samples, as was evidenced by multiple techniques (XPS, UV–vis, FTIR, and Raman characterization), denotes the existence of oxygen vacancies. Hence, adsorption of molecular oxygen could occur in the CeO2 sample as described in the second stage of Fig. 10. Once the temperature increases, the CO(a) signal intensity decreases while the bands corresponding to CO2 (gas) was growing up, appearing in a temperature higher than 160 °C (2370 and 2344 cm-1). Above this temperature, the production of carbon dioxide increased significantly. Possibly the decrement of the bands of CO adsorbed on the Ceᵟ+ sites below of 160 °C, could be due to the thermic desorption, while above this temperature the Ce+n−CO species were converted to CO2. At the same temperature, the adsorbed O2 dissociates at the surface vacancies and then reacted with the CO bonded on Ceᵟ+ sites to give rise to a CO2 molecule as in the third stage according to Fig. 10. Then, the remaining oxygen atom adsorbed on the vacancy interacts with another CO molecule to produce an additional molecule of CO2 (step 4, Fig. 10). The data displayed in the previous sections demonstrate that the Ru addition to pure cerium oxide drastically improves the catalytic performance in the CO oxidation reaction. The CO conversion was increased and the temperature of the onset production of CO2 started at approximately 40 °C (Fig. 6). This improvement was due to an increase of the surface adsorption sites for molecular oxygen on CeO2 (namely increased number of oxygen vacancies) and by the lowering of the O2 activation temperature promoted by the presence of Ru species at the surface. The FTIR measurements under reaction conditions during CO oxidation on Ru-containing CeO2 catalyst revealed that the incorporation of ruthenium drastically favored the CO adsorption. Because bands of carbonyls ruthenium in the range of 1870−2058 cm−1 were detected. Additionally, the absorption bands at 2174 and 2120 cm−1 assigned to CO linked to Ce+4 and Ce+3 sites, respectively were observed. Our results suggest that the CO adsorbs on both cerium support and ruthenium sites. The absorption bands of CO on Ce+n sites decreased their intensities as a function of temperature increment, reaching their minimum intensity at 160 °C (around this temperature the maximum conversion was reached), above which they remain approximately constant. The intensity of the absorption bands of ruthenium dicarbonyl species (2058 and 1988 cm−1) was increased until 160 °C, then above this temperature, the intensity of their bands began to slightly decrease when the temperature was increased. However, the increase in the CO conversion was poor, therefore it cannot be established whether these species could participate in the reaction mechanism or are only are thermodynamically desorbed. Furthermore, around this temperature and higher the absorption bands of carbonyl species bonded in a linear and bridged form on Ru sites (2030 1968, 1945 and 1870 cm−1) increased their intensity during FTIR measurements, suggested that these absorbed species were accumulated on the surface. Then, based on our results, and based on the surface species that changed until the maximum conversion was reached, at a lower temperature, the CO conversion could be over oxygen vacancies, even the Ce+n−CO species could participate in the catalysis. Fig. 11 shows the proposed surface reaction route for the CO oxidation over Ru-containing CeO2 material obtained from our FTIR data under operando conditions. This route is analogous to the one shown in Fig. 10, though the incorporation of ruthenium enhances the formation of oxygen vacancies, which can be related to the improvement of both CO adsorption and surface O2 activation at lower temperatures. In the first part of the surface mechanism proposal, the CO(g) is adsorbed on the Ru species and over cationic Ce3+ sites (step 1, Fig. 11), while the molecular oxygen is adsorbed on the oxygen vacancies (step 2, Fig. 11). The activation of adsorbed oxygen can be carried out by the surface ruthenium species (in isolated form or nanoparticles) neighboring to oxygen vacancies, generating oxygen atoms that could react with the CO adsorbed on Ceδ+ sites to produce CO2 (g) molecules (step 3, Fig. 11). After CO2 desorption, newly CO(g) molecules could be adsorbed on the free Ceδ+ sites (step 3, Fig. 11). Finally, the surface oxygen atoms of CeO2 in the vicinity of Ru sites could react with the adsorbed carbonyl species on Ceδ+ sites, to produce another CO2 (g) molecules, regenerating the initial oxygen vacancies and the Ce3+ sites (step 4, Fig. 11), however, the adsorbed CO molecules on the Ru species, apparently they do not participate in the oxidation process, at least the change of these species was not detected. It can be assumed that CO oxidation occurred at low temperatures on the generated oxygen vacancies. Following step 4, we assume that CO molecules were adsorbed again on the Ce3+ sites, thus begin the catalytic cycle again, as stated in step 1. In counterpart, the dynamic of the bands of ruthenium carbonyl species is more complex, incrementing their intensity until 160 °C and decreasing above this point (Figs. 8 and 9). Cause above 160 °C the conversion is very low (approximately 8%) this behavior cannot be associated accurately to their transformation towards CO2 or the thermic desorption as CO in gas-phase. However, based on our results, we can assume that the ruthenium incorporation drastically favored the adsorption of CO, even though the highest contribution of the incorporation of ruthenium species is that it increased the number of oxygen vacancies in the ceria surface, therefore the dissociation of adsorbed oxygen was improved. These observations can be valid until temperatures close to their maximum conversion, above them various phenomena could occur that are not completely clear with the results achieved in this work. Regarding the sample with a high ruthenium load, the mechanism is similar to Ru(1.5)CeO2 sample. However, the higher metal load promotes the formation of ruthenium nanoparticles Ru, hence diminishes the formation of isolated Ru species, as indicated by DRX, XPS, Raman, TPR, and DRS-UV–vis results, and consequently a decrease in the number of oxygen vacancies [20,64]. Therefore, we can assume that the less catalytic activity observed in this sample, concerning Ru(1.5)CeO2 catalyst, could be associated with a lesser supply of oxygen for CO oxidation. 5 Conclusions The presence of Ce+3 sites on pure CeO2 support has been evidenced through multiple characterization techniques (XPS, UV–vis, FTIR, and Raman), related to the existence of oxygen vacancies on the surface. The CO oxidation reaction mechanism on cerium oxide was associated with surface oxygen vacancies sites, which promoted the dissociative-oxygen adsorption. As observed in samples containing ruthenium, its presence enhances the formation of surface oxygen vacancies, which favor the oxygen mobility from the ceria lattice toward the CO oxidation. Also, we observed that the ruthenium incorporation drastically favors the adsorption of CO. The catalysts with lower Ru content (1.5 wt.%) show higher catalytic activity than those containing a greater Ru loading (3% wt.). The lower catalytic performance of the sample with 3 % wt of ruthenium, could be explained by a higher amount of ruthenium species exposed on the surface, which covered to a great extent the support, drastically decreasing the contribution of oxygen provided by ceria lattice towards the reaction. coredata.dc:description: New insight on the understanding of the reaction mechanisms during the CO oxidation over Ru-containing CeO2 catalysts was reported. A set of ruthenium high surface area CeO2 oxides, with two different Ru loadings, was prepared for studying the evolution of Ru and Ce species during CO oxidation reaction, using a reaction mixture of 1 % CO, 0.5 % O2, N2 balance and a contact time W/FCO = 7.4 gcat h molCO −1. The samples were characterized by SBET, XRD, DRS UV–vis, TPR, Raman spectroscopy, and XPS. Furthermore, the samples were investigated by FTIR measurements during CO oxidation under reaction conditions. The catalysts with low Ru loading (1.5 wt.%) presented higher catalytic activity than those containing a higher Ru loading (3 % wt.). The catalytic activity test results strongly depend on electronic changes observed at the interface/surface of ceria support. The characterization results and FTIR investigation during CO oxidation show that the presence of ruthenium species modifies the electronic properties of the ceria surface promoting a change at their surface where a redox-mechanism was detected. This causes the formation of surface oxygen vacancies which promotes oxygen mobility from the ceria lattice contributing to the CO oxidation. The ruthenium incorporation drastically favors the CO adsorption (carbonyl and dicarbonyl species). However, our FTIR data not shown a direct correlation between the ruthenium-carbonyl species (linear and bridged form) on the CO transformation. Further, the presence of ruthenium enhances the formation of surface oxygen vacancies, which favor the oxygen mobility from the ceria lattice toward the CO oxidation. It was found that at low temperatures (close down to the maximum conversion), the CO oxidation preferably happened on oxygen vacancy sites.
coredata.dc:title: FTIR investigation under reaction conditions during CO oxidation over Ru(x)-CeO2 catalysts
